title: Bilbao
text:
Bilbao (, , ; ) is a city in northern <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, the largest city in the <a href="Provinces%20of%20Spain">province</a> of <a href="Biscay">Biscay</a> and in the <a href="Basque%20Country%20%28greater%20region%29">Basque Country</a> as a whole. It is also the largest city proper in northern Spain. Bilbao is the <a href="List%20of%20cities%20in%20Spain%20by%20population">tenth largest city</a> in Spain, with a population of 345,141 as of 2015. The <a href="Bilbao%20metropolitan%20area">Bilbao metropolitan area</a> has 1,037,847 inhabitants, making it one of the most populous <a href="metropolitan%20area">metropolitan area</a>s in northern Spain; with a population of 875,552 the <a href="Comarcas%20of%20the%20Basque%20Country">comarca</a> of <a href="Greater%20Bilbao">Greater Bilbao</a> is the fifth-largest urban area in Spain. Bilbao is also the main urban area in what is defined as the <a href="Basque%20Country%20%28greater%20region%29">Greater Basque region</a>.
Bilbao is situated in the north-central part of Spain, some south of the <a href="Bay%20of%20Biscay">Bay of Biscay</a>, where the economic social development is located, where the <a href="estuary%20of%20Bilbao">estuary of Bilbao</a> is formed. Its main urban core is surrounded by two small <a href="mountain%20range">mountain range</a>s with an average elevation of . Its climate is shaped by the Bay of Biscay low-pressure systems and mild air, moderating summer temperatures by <a href="Iberian%20Peninsula">Iberian</a> standards, with low sunshine and high rainfall. The annual temperature range is low for its latitude.
After its foundation in the early 14th century by <a href="Diego%20L%C3%B3pez%20V%20de%20Haro">Diego López V de Haro</a>, head of the powerful <a href="House%20of%20Haro">Haro</a> family, Bilbao was one of the commercial hubs of the <a href="Basque%20Country%20%28autonomous%20community%29">Basque Country</a> that enjoyed significant importance in the <a href="Crown%20of%20Castile">Crown of Castile</a>. This was due to its thriving <a href="Port%20of%20Bilbao">port activity</a> based on the export of wool and iron commodities extracted from the Biscayan quarries to all over Europe. Throughout the nineteenth century and the beginning of the twentieth, Bilbao experienced heavy industrialisation, making it the center of the second-most industrialised region of Spain, behind <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>. At the same time an extraordinary population explosion prompted the annexation of several adjacent municipalities. Nowadays, Bilbao is a vigorous <a href="service%20sector">service city</a> that is experiencing an ongoing social, economic, and aesthetic revitalisation process, started by the iconic <a href="Bilbao%20Guggenheim%20Museum">Bilbao Guggenheim Museum</a>, and continued by infrastructure investments, such as the <a href="Bilbao%20Airport">airport terminal</a>, the <a href="Metro%20Bilbao">rapid transit system</a>, the <a href="Bilbao%20tram">tram line</a>, the <a href="Azkuna%20Zentroa">Azkuna Zentroa</a>, and the currently under development <a href="Abandoibarra">Abandoibarra</a> and <a href="Zorrozaurre">Zorrozaurre</a> <a href="urban%20renewal">renewal</a> projects.
Bilbao is also home to <a href="association%20football">football</a> team <a href="Athletic%20Bilbao">Athletic Club</a>, a significant symbol for <a href="Basque%20nationalism">Basque nationalism</a> due to its <a href="Athletic%20Bilbao%20signing%20policy">promotion of only Basque players</a> and being one of the most successful clubs in Spanish football history.
On 19 May 2010, the city of Bilbao was recognised with the Lee Kuan Yew World City Prize, awarded by the city state of <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a>, in collaboration with the Swedish <a href="Nobel%20Prize">Nobel Academy</a>. Considered the Nobel Prize for <a href="urbanism">urbanism</a>, it was handed out on 29 June 2010. On 7 January 2013, its mayor, <a href="I%C3%B1aki%20Azkuna">Iñaki Azkuna</a>, received the 2012 <a href="World%20Mayor">World Mayor</a> Prize awarded every two years by the British foundation The City Mayors Foundation, in recognition of the urban transformation experienced by the Biscayan capital since the 1990s. On 8 November 2017, Bilbao was chosen the Best European City 2018 at The Urbanism Awards 2018, awarded by the international organisation The Academy of Urbanism.
Etymology.
The official name of the town is Bilbao, as known in most languages of the world. <a href="Euskaltzaindia">Euskaltzaindia</a>, the official regulatory institution of the <a href="Basque%20language">Basque language</a>, has agreed that between the two possible names existing in Basque, "Bilbao" and "Bilbo", the historical name is "Bilbo", while "Bilbao" is the official name. Although the term "Bilbo" does not appear in old documents, in the play "<a href="The%20Merry%20Wives%20of%20Windsor">The Merry Wives of Windsor</a>" by <a href="William%20Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>, there is a reference to swords presumably made of Biscayan iron which he calls "<a href="bilbo%20%28sword%29">bilboes</a>", suggesting that it is a word used since at least the sixteenth century.
There is no consensus among historians about the origin of the name. Generally accepted accounts state that prior to the 12th century the independent rulers of the territory, named Lords of Zubialdea, were also known as Lords of Bilbao la Vieja ("Old Bilbao"). The symbols of their patrimony are the tower and church used in the shield of Bilbao to this day. One possible origin was suggested by the engineer <a href="Evaristo%20de%20Churruca%20y%20Brunet">Evaristo de Churruca</a>. He said that it was a Basque custom to name a place after its location. For Bilbao this would be the result of the union of the Basque words for river and cove: "Bil-Ibaia-Bao". The historian José Tussel Gómez argues that it is just a natural evolution of the Spanish words "bello vado", beautiful river crossing. On the other hand, according to the writer Esteban Calle Iturrino, the name derives from the two settlements that existed on both banks of the estuary, rather than from the estuary itself. The first, where the present <a href="Casco%20Viejo">Casco Viejo</a> is located, would be called "billa", which means stacking in Basque, after the configuration of the buildings. The second, on the left bank, where now <a href="Bilbo%20Zarra">Bilbao La Vieja</a> is located, would be called "vaho", Spanish for mist or steam. From the union of these two derives the name Bilbao, which was also written as "Bilvao" and "Biluao", as documented in its <a href="municipal%20charter">municipal charter</a>.
An "-ao" ending is also present in nearby <a href="Sestao">Sestao</a> and <a href="Ugao-Miraballes">Ugao</a>, that could be explained from Basque "aho", "mouth".
Demonym.
The demonym is "bilbaíno, -a", although the popular pronunciation "bilbaino/a" (sic) is also frequent. In <a href="euskera">euskera</a> it is "bilbotar", which is sometimes also used in Spanish, generally within the Basque Country. 
The village is affectionately known by its inhabitants as the "" meaning "hole", since it is surrounded by mountains. The nickname "botxero" is derived from this nickname. Another nickname that Bilbao receives is that of "chimbos", which comes from birds that were hunted in large numbers in these places during the 19th century.
The titles, the flag and the coat of arms are Bilbao's traditional symbols and belong to its historic patrimony, being used in formal acts, for the identification and decoration of specific places or for the validation of documents.
Bilbao holds the historic category of township ("villa"), with the titles of "Very noble and very loyal and unbeaten" ("Muy Noble y Muy Leal e Invicta"). It was the <a href="Catholic%20Monarchs">Catholic Monarchs</a> who awarded the title "Noble Town" ("Noble Villa") on 20 September 1475. <a href="Philip%20III%20of%20Spain">Philip III of Spain</a>, via a letter in 1603 awarded the town the titles of "Very noble and very loyal". After the <a href="Siege%20of%20Bilbao%20%281836%29">Siege of Bilbao</a>, during the <a href="First%20Carlist%20War">First Carlist War</a>, on 25 December 1836, the title of "Unbeaten" was added.
